page.title: The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights

revision.text:
{{ Infobox attraction | name = The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights | logo = Osborne Family Lights Logo.jpg | logo_width = | location = Disney's Hollywood Studios | section = [[Disney's Hollywood Studios#Streets of America|Streets of America]] | status = Closed | cost = | soft_opened = | opened = 1995{{cite web|title=The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights presented by Siemens|url=https://disneyworld.disney.go.com/events-tours/hollywood-studios/osborne-family-spectacle-of-dancing-lights/|website=disneyworld.com|publisher=Walt Disney World|accessdate=30 November 2014}} | closed = January 6, 2016 | previousattraction = | replacement = | coordinates = {{coord|28|21|18|N|81|33|35|W}} | type = | manufacturer = | designer = Jennings Osborne | theme = [[Christmas]] | music = [[#Current Dancing Song List|Christmas Music]] | sitearea_sqft = 59860 | sitearea_sqm = | virtual_queue_name = | virtual_queue_image = | virtual_queue_status= | custom_label_1 = Sponsor | custom_value_1 = [[Siemens]] (2005-2016){{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Jerry|title=Siemens signs on as Disney sponsor|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/2005-11-09/news/DISNEYSIEMENS09_1_siemens-ag-walt-disney-disney-world|website=articles.orlandosentinel.com|publisher=Orlando Sentinel|accessdate=13 December 2015}}{{cite web|title=Siemens and The Walt Disney Company Announce Strategic Alliance; Siemens Will Sponsor Attractions and Implement New Technologies across a Range of Disney Businesses|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20051108005368/en/Siemens-Walt-Disney-Company-Announce-Strategic-Alliance|website=businesswire.com|publisher=BusinessWire|accessdate=13 December 2015}}
[[Osram Sylvania|Sylvania]] (2005-2013)In 2013, Siemens took over sponsorship, replacing [[Osram Sylvania|Sylvania]], the company's former subsidiary; the brand's owner [[Osram]] was spun off into its own company on July 5, 2013 | custom_label_2 = Begins | custom_value_2 = November 6 | custom_label_3 = Ends | custom_value_3 = January 6 | custom_label_4 = Website | custom_value_4 = [https://disneyworld.disney.go.com/events-tours/hollywood-studios/osborne-family-spectacle-of-dancing-lights/ The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights presented by Siemens] | custom_label_5 = | custom_value_5 = | image = Panorama of The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights.jpg | imagedimensions = | caption = Panorama of The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights in 2014 }} '''The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights''' was a display of [[Christmas]] lights and decorations at [[Disney's Hollywood Studios]] at the [[Walt Disney World Resort]] near [[Orlando, Florida]]. Initially constructed by an [[Arkansas]] businessman as a gift for his six-year-old daughter, the display became one of the most popular attractions during the park's holiday season. ==History== Jennings Osborne (1943-2011{{cite web|title=Jennings Osborne dies following long illness|url=http://www.katv.com/story/15150613/jennings-osborne-dies-following-long-illness|website=katv.com|publisher=KATV|accessdate=11 September 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Miller|first1=Stephen|title=An Ostentatious Provider of Well-Lit Christmases|url=http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424053111903635604576476610301927954|website=wsj.com|publisher=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=11 September 2015}}{{cite web|title=Jennings Osborne Obituary|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/macon/obituary.aspx?n=jennings-osborne&pid=152790344|website=legacy.com|publisher=Macon Telegraph|accessdate=11 September 2015}}), along with his wife Mitzi, founded the "Arkansas Research Medical Testing Center"{{cite web|last1=Terhune|first1=E. Sue|title=Famous Unrelated (as far as we know) Osbornes|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~tlosborne/Osborne/Osbornehistory/Jenningsosborne/jenningsosborne.htm|website=ancestry.com|accessdate=11 September 2015}} in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]] in 1968.{{cite web|last1=Friedman|first1=Mark|title=Medical testing labs on track to open soon|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Medical+testing+labs+on+track+to+open+soon.-a0219657410|website=thefreelibrary.com|publisher=The Free Library by Farlex|accessdate=11 September 2015}} The business' success allowed him and his wife to eventually purchase a large estate in the middle of town in 1976. In 1980 the Osbornes had a daughter, Allison Brianne Osborne, nicknamed Breezy. In 1986, Breezy asked her father if they could decorate their home in lights. Osborne complied, stringing 1000 lights around their home. "Each year after that, it got bigger and bigger," Osborne would later recall.[http://www.jenningsosbornefamily.com/mainframe.html Jennings Osborne Family] Eventually Osborne purchased the two properties adjacent to his own and expanded the display into them. By 1993, the display had over three million lights. Some of the more prominent features included: * an illuminated globe, with Little Rock and [[Bethlehem]] marked, mounted in the back yard; * two rotating carousels of lights, placed on each end of the estate's circular driveway; * a {{convert|70|ft|m|adj=on}}-tall Christmas tree of lights with 80,000 lights in three colored layers, mounted atop the home's kitchen; and * a canopy of 30,000 red lights over a section of the driveway.Disney's Hollywood Studios audio spiel, 2007 edition The lights were extremely popular in both in Arkansas and around the world, as news crews often visited to film the display. Since their house was located on one of the busiest streets in Little Rock, it eventually caused severe traffic issues, and lots of complaints. ===Legal issues=== The display grew bigger every year, and by 1993, was lit for 35 days during the Christmas season, from sunset to about midnight every day. Six neighbors filed a lawsuit, saying traffic congestion made trips to the corner store take two hours, and they feared emergency vehicles could not get down the street. Osborne responded by adding three million more lights.{{cite web|title=1 man's festival of lights is some neighbors' eyesore|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1994-12-21/news/1994355045_1_arkansas-supreme-osborne-home-supreme-court|website=articles.baltimoresun.com|publisher=Baltimore Sun|accessdate=11 September 2015}} The county court ordered an injunction against the display, limiting it to 15 days and directing that it be lighted only from 7 p.m. to 10:30 p.m. Osborne appealed first to the [[Arkansas Supreme Court]] and lost, then in 1994 to the [[United States Supreme Court]], where Justice [[Clarence Thomas]] refused to halt the order. In 1995, the state Supreme Court shut down the display altogether. The Osbornes continued to have a light display, but on a much smaller scale well into the 2000s. After the [[9/11|September 11th attacks of 2001]], they erected an enormous lighted American flag with the words "God Bless America and God Bless George W. Bush" across the top and bottom of the flag. This display remained up for several years, even as the strands of lights went out and the message was barely readable. ===Display acquired by Disney=== The story of the light display's court case brought national attention, including offers from several cities to host the display. Walt Disney World project director John Phelan contacted Osborne's attorney about moving the display to the Orlando resort, and eventually discussed the potential move with Osborne himself. Osborne was intrigued by the offer, but initially understood that Disney wanted to put the display on another residential street in Orlando. What Phelan actually offered was to install the display on "Residential Street," a back-lot section at Disney's Hollywood Studios theme park (then known by its original name, the Disney-MGM Studios). Being a fan of the resort himself, and realizing where the display would go, Osborne accepted Disney's offer. In 1995, the display was set up on Residential Street as "The Osborne Family Spectacle of Lights," becoming an immediate success. ==Disney's Hollywood Studios display== [[File:MGM SpectacleLights.JPG|thumb|The Osbourne lights in Streets of America.]] Residential Street was visited using the [[Studio Backlot Tour]]'s tram vehicles. When the light display was in place, however, the tram tours would stop before sunset, allowing guests to walk among the displays. Initially the display was purely the original lights from the Osborne estate, but in subsequent years the display was augmented to its current size of over five million lights. The display's Disney caretakers have also added a number of [[hidden Mickey]]s into the lights. The 2007 edition of the display featured over 40 of the icons. The display was made up of over {{convert|10|mile|km}} of rope lighting connected by another {{convert|30|mile|km}} of extension cords. The extension cords and lights were held together using two million ties. It took 20,000 man-hours to install the display each holiday season, starting in September. The lights were turned on at dusk each night, starting in mid-November and running into the first week of January, and required 800,000 [[watt]]s of electricity. In 2004, the park began construction on a new arena for its upcoming ''Lights! Motors! Action! Extreme Stunt Show'', set to open in 2005. Part of the construction included the demolition of Residential Street, thus necessitating another move of the display. The solution was to move it to another part of the park, the New York Street set (now known as the Streets of America). As part of the move, the Studios added an artificial snow effect to the display, made up of 33 snow machines that use {{convert|100|USgal|L|abbr=on}} of fluid per evening. In 2005, [[Osram Sylvania|Sylvania]] became the presenting sponsor of the lights, as part of parent company [[Siemens AG|Siemens's]] long-term sponsorship deal with the [[The Walt Disney Company|Walt Disney Company's]] theme parks, which also included the [[Spaceship Earth (Disney)|Spaceship Earth]] and ''[[IllumiNations: Reflections of Earth]]'' attractions at [[Epcot]]. For the 2006 edition, the park added over 1500 dimmer relay circuits and control switches to the display to enable the lights to dim on and off electronically. The relays were choreographed to a musical score, and the display was given its current name. In 2011 the display had a major overhaul, all the lights were swapped out for LED lights including all the ropelight. During this overhaul the lighting control was updated to a "state of the art" entertainment lighting system using light control boards from the company [http://lightorama.com Light-O-Rama]. This means all the previously choreographed dancing sequences had to be redone. While all these updates the production team wanted to change one more major element to the display, the canopy. The canopy in previous years was all red and separated in only 8 circuits, 4 on each side; now each light has 3 completely controllable LEDs (Red, Green, Blue) giving the canopy an almost video-like appearance. Now the canopy has 21,600 pixels capable of over 16 million colors. In 2013, Siemens took over sponsorship, replacing [[Osram Sylvania|Sylvania]], the company's former subsidiary; the brand's owner [[Osram]] was spun off into its own company on July 5, 2013{{cite web|title=Osram shares begin trading on the Frankfurt and Munich Stock Exchanges|url=http://ledsmagazine.com/news/10/7/5|publisher=LEDs Magazine|accessdate=July 10, 2013}} In 2014, reserved viewing of the lights was offered for the first time as part of a "Frozen Holiday Premium Package" themed around the movie Frozen.{{cite web|last1=Fickley-Baker|first1=Jennifer|title=Make Your Holidays Sparkle With This Disney’s Hollywood Studios Frozen Holiday Premium Package|url=http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2014/10/make-your-holidays-sparkle-with-this-disneys-hollywood-studios-frozen-holiday-premium-package/|website=disneyparksblog.com|publisher=Disney Parks|accessdate=11 September 2015}} On September 11, 2015, Disney announced that the 2015 holiday season will be the final season for the Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights, with the final performance scheduled for January 3, 2016.{{cite web|last1=Smith|first1=Thomas|title=Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights: Celebrate a De‘light’ful Holiday Tradition One More Time|url=http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2015/09/osborne-family-spectacle-of-dancing-lights-celebrate-a-delightful-holiday-tradition-one-more-time/|website=disneyparksblog.com|publisher=Disney Parks|accessdate=11 September 2015}} On January 3, 2016, it was announced the current season would be extended by 3 more nights, with the final performance rescheduled for January 6, 2016.{{cite web|title=BREAKING: Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights Extended Until Wednesday|url=http://wdwnt.com/blog/2016/01/breaking-osborne-family-spectacle-of-dancing-lights-extended-until-wednesday/|publisher=WDW News Today|access-date= 4 January 2016}} The final songs the lights danced to were "[[Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas]]" and "[[Mickey Mouse Club]] Alma Mater". ==="Dancing Lights"=== Whenever a choreographed song was played the lights "dance" to the music. After each performance, the lights remained steady for about seven minutes before "dancing" again to another selection; other holiday selections play during the intermissions, along with recorded "live" segments from a fictional radio station (with Arnie and Anne) and visits from Disney characters. The dancing segments cycled roughly every 40–60 minutes. ===Last Dancing Song List=== * "Christmas Eve (Sarajevo 12-24)" by [[Trans-Siberian Orchestra]]{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FeSLcOUSwCo|title=Osborne Lights 2011|date=14 November 2011|work=YouTube}} * "Jingle Bells" by [[Barbra Streisand]]{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2LubG1vP118|title=Disney's Osborne Lights- Jingle Bells in HD|date=20 December 2008|work=YouTube}} * "A Mad Russian's Christmas" by Trans-Siberian Orchestra * "Feliz Navidad" by [[José Feliciano]] * "Here Comes Santa Claus" by [[Elvis Presley]] * "Parade of the Wooden Soldiers" by [[Arthur Fiedler]] & [[Boston Pops Orchestra]] * "Nuttin' for Christmas" by the [[Plain White T's]] (from the special ''[[Prep & Landing: Naughty vs. Nice]]''){{cite av media|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iP1GIepb_mc|title=I'm Getting Nuttin' For Christmas (I'm Getting Nothing for Christmas) OSBORNE LIGHTS|date=25 November 2011|work=YouTube}} * "Christmas is Starting Now" by [[Big Bad Voodoo Daddy]] (from the ''[[Phineas and Ferb Christmas Vacation]]'' special){{cite av media|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8NYD0xA8Ob8|title=Osborne Lights - Christmas is Starting Now|date=20 November 2012|work=YouTube}} * "Winter Wonderland" (Original arrangement by Dan Stamper){{cite web|last1=Slater|first1=Shawn|title=There’s Always Something New at The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights at Disney’s Hollywood Studios|url=http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2012/11/theres-always-something-new-at-the-osborne-family-spectacle-of-dancing-lights-at-disneys-hollywood-studios/|website=disneyparksblog.com|publisher=Disney Parks|accessdate=11 September 2015}}{{cite av media|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ThtCho926ec|title=New "Winter Wonderland" sequence in the Osborne Spectacle of Dancing Lights at Walt Disney World|date=12 November 2012|work=YouTube}} * "What's This?" by [[Danny Elfman]] (from [[Tim Burton]]'s [[The Nightmare Before Christmas]]) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160105091844/https://disneyworld.disney.go.com/events-tours/hollywood-studios/osborne-family-spectacle-of-dancing-lights/ Archived version of The Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights site] {{Disney's Hollywood Studios}} {{Walt Disney World}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Osborne Family Spectacle of Dancing Lights, The}} [[Category:Disney's Hollywood Studios]] [[Category:Former Walt Disney Parks and Resorts attractions]] [[Category:Amusement rides that closed in 2016]]
